verdict: Very early-stage account with minimal spend; $27 CPA is promising but needs more data and structural improvements

checks.name: Conversion actions defined
checks.finding: 3 conversions from 13 clicks (23.1% CVR) — tracking appears functional but very small sample

checks.name: Micro vs macro separation
checks.finding: 23.1% CVR is suspiciously high even for tree services — verify only calls/form fills are Primary

checks.name: Conversion value assignment
checks.finding: No conversion values — tree service jobs range from $200 to $5,000+. Values would help prioritize

checks.name: Search term audit recency
checks.finding: Very low volume (13 clicks) — sample too small to identify waste patterns

checks.name: Negative keyword lists exist
checks.finding: Tree service queries attract DIY and informational traffic — negatives needed even at low volume

checks.name: Wasted spend assessment
checks.finding: $27 CPA is very efficient for tree services. 23.1% CVR (if real) indicates strong targeting

checks.name: Campaign naming convention
checks.finding: Date-based naming with clear identifiers: [February 3] [Search] [Search Partners] [AI MAX]

checks.name: Campaign count per objective
checks.finding: 2 campaigns with $81.78 total spend — fragmentation risk at very low budget

checks.name: Brand vs Non-Brand separation
checks.finding: No brand campaign. Both campaigns target tree removal non-brand

checks.name: Search Partners test
checks.finding: Testing Search Partners vs No Partners — good practice to measure incremental value

checks.name: AI MAX feature
checks.finding: AI MAX enabled on one campaign — automatically expands keywords, which at $81 spend may cause waste

checks.name: Search CTR performance
checks.finding: 2.24% combined CTR is low — AI MAX campaign: 2.08% CTR, No AI campaign: 33.3% CTR (1/3 but tiny sample)

checks.name: Keyword volume
checks.finding: 580 total impressions in 30 days — extremely low. Budget or targeting too restrictive

checks.name: AI MAX impact
checks.finding: AI MAX campaign drives 99.6% of spend ($81.47 vs $0.31) — No AI campaign essentially starved of budget

checks.name: CTR vs industry benchmark
checks.finding: 2.24% CTR vs ~5% tree service benchmark — below average. Ad copy may need improvement

checks.name: Ad freshness
checks.finding: Campaign started February 3 — very new. Need more time to assess performance

checks.name: Smart bidding strategy active
checks.finding: With only 3 conversions, smart bidding cannot optimize. Max Clicks may be more appropriate at this stage

checks.name: Geographic targeting accuracy
checks.finding: Tree services are hyperlocal — verify service area radius is appropriate

checks.name: Budget adequacy
checks.finding: $6.29/day average spend is very low for tree services. Need minimum $20-30/day to gather meaningful data

quickWins.action: Increase daily budget to at least $20-30/day — $6.29/day is insufficient to gather optimization data
Consolidate to 1 campaign — at $81.78 total spend, splitting into 2 campaigns fragments data
Verify conversion tracking — 23.1% CVR is high; confirm only legitimate leads are Primary
Improve ad copy — 2.24% CTR is below benchmark. Add specific services, response time, free estimates
Add negative keywords for DIY, rental, cost/price informational queries

items: Consolidate to single campaign to aggregate all data
Improve ad copy with specific service callouts and unique selling propositions
Expand keywords beyond just tree removal — add tree trimming, stump grinding, emergency tree service
Use Max Clicks bidding until reaching 15+ conversions/month threshold
Consider LSA for tree services — often cost-effective for home services
Once at 15+ conversions/month, switch to Max Conversions bidding
Test geographic expansion if initial service area is performing
Add brand campaign if business develops brand search volume
Build remarketing audiences for seasonal re-engagement (storm season, spring cleanup)
